contentItem.text: The bullfrog has the amazing ability to eat basically whatever they can fit into their huge mouths and stuff down their throats. Even though insects make up a large portion of the bullfrog’s diet, they are an equal opportunity eater. Also eating mice, turtles, snakes, birds, other bullfrogs, fish and even bats.

If a bullfrog can catch an animal and cram it down its throat, they’ll eat it. When bullfrogs attack with a quick strike of their giant mouths, their eyes close and retract and their sticky tongues wraps around the prey.

mediaItem.uri: /wildkratts/media/creaturepedia/28/05_Food Asset_Animation clip of a bullfrog eating a worm_1.f4v

contentItem.text: The American bullfrog originally inhabited only central and eastern North and Central America, but has now been introduced to western North America, South America, Europe, Australia, and Asia.

Bullfrog eggs, tadpoles, and smaller frogs have lots of predators including raccoons, birds, snakes, turtles, and fish. Adult bullfrogs are too big for many predators, but that doesn’t stop predators like raccoons and great blue herons from gobbling them up.
Bullfrogs hibernate in the winter. They swim to the bottom and nestle on soft mud of a pond or lake and stay there all winter long.
